newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong stocks end modestly higher, consolidate.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong stocks end modestly higher, consolidate.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks ended with modest gains on Monday, with a fall in the U.S. long bond yield and gains in the local futures market allowing prices to stabilise after heavy losses last week, analysts said.
The Hang Seng Index rose 31.36 points, or 0.24 percent, to 13,144.62. Last week it shed 547.24 points. Turnover was HK$7.42 billion compared with HK$10.49 billion on Friday.
"I think it is just consolidating around these levels," said Richard Verin, head of equities trading at CS First Boston.
"I think that the fact the futures have held up well tells you that there is come consolidation," he said.
February Hang Seng Index futures rose 65 points to 13,205, trading at a premium to the cash market and providing support.

"Last week the drop in the market was triggered by futures trading and today it seems like there is some support for the futures market and selling pressure reduced," said Frederick Tsang, head of research at PrimeEast Securities.
Brokers said a rise of 17/32 in the U.S long bond on Friday, bringing the yield to 6.53 percent, had been encouraging.
But after last week's drop in local share prices, analysts said investors remained cautious.
"We particularly saw most of the selling pressure concentrated on the big cap stocks and that is not a very good sign. We need to see how the market trades this week," said Tsang.
Verin said European and U.S. investors had also been showing some concern about political developments in Hong Kong. "I do think that there is foreign selling," he said.
But he saw support for the Hang Seng Index at 13,000 points with the upside limited to around 13,500.
"There is no flow of news at the moment to push it up," said Verin.
Gains in major blue chips HSBC Holdings and Cheung Kong helped lift the Hang Seng higher. HSBC rose HK$1.00 to HK$184.50 and Cheung Kong rose HK$0.75 to HK$72.50.

Hongkong Telecom fell HK$0.05 to HK$13.00. Analysts said that a global pact reached this weekend on opening the telecommunications industry to competition would have no immediate impact on Hongkong Telecom.
Shares in South China Morning Post rose HK$0.65 to HK$7.00. The company reported interim net profit last week of HK$379 million compared with HK$427 million.
